articles.headline: Vatican Priest Likens Criticism Over Abuse to Anti-Semitism
articles.snippet: A Vatican priest compared the uproar over sexual abuse scandals to the persecution of Jews, but a spokesman said the words were not “an official statement.”
articles.abstract: A Vatican priest compared the uproar over sexual abuse scandals to the persecution of Jews, but a spokesman said the words were not “an official statement.”
articles.lead_paragraph: ROME — A senior Vatican priest, speaking before Pope Benedict XVI at a Good Friday service, compared the world’s outrage at sexual abuse scandals in the Catholic Church to the persecution of the Jews, prompting angry responses from victims’ advocates and consternation from Jewish groups.
articles.byline: By Daniel J. Wakin and Rachel Donadio

articles.headline: Help Paying Mortgages Elicits Anger
articles.snippet: Many angry readers said taxpayers should not be helping unemployed homeowners with their mortgages.
articles.abstract: Many angry readers said taxpayers should not be helping unemployed homeowners with their mortgages.
articles.lead_paragraph: The angry comments flooded in after the federal government announced it was expanding its program to assist unemployed homeowners, as well as borrowers who owe more on their mortgages than their homes are now worth.

articles.headline: The Unpaid Intern, Legal or Not
articles.snippet: The number of unpaid internships has climbed in recent years, leading officials to worry that employers are illegally using interns for free labor.
articles.abstract: The number of unpaid internships has climbed in recent years, leading officials to worry that employers are illegally using interns for free labor.
articles.lead_paragraph: With job openings scarce for young people, the number of unpaid internships has climbed in recent years, leading federal and state regulators to worry that more employers are illegally using such internships for free labor.

articles.headline: For Pro Athletes, Practice That’s All in the Thumbs
articles.snippet: Professional athletes say that video games improve their physical and mental skills, in part because the quality of the sports simulations has gotten so good.
articles.abstract: Professional athletes say that video games improve their physical and mental skills, in part because the quality of the sports simulations has gotten so good.
articles.lead_paragraph: Video games like Nintendo’s Wii Fit or Electronics Arts’ Madden N.F.L. series aren’t just for armchair athletes.

articles.headline: Pension Funds Still Waiting for Big Payoff From Private Equity
articles.snippet: The 10 largest U.S. public pension funds have paid firms $17 billion in fees since 2000, but few ended up collecting the large returns that managers often held out to attract pension money.
articles.abstract: The 10 largest U.S. public pension funds have paid firms $17 billion in fees since 2000, but few ended up collecting the large returns that managers often held out to attract pension money.
articles.lead_paragraph: Private equity deal-makers, those kings of corporate buyouts, made billions for themselves when times were good. But some of their biggest investors, public pension funds, are still waiting for the hefty rewards they were promised.

articles.headline: H. Edward Roberts, PC Pioneer, Dies at 68
articles.snippet: Dr. Roberts made an early contribution to modern computing and was a mentor to Bill Gates.
articles.abstract: Dr. Roberts made an early contribution to modern computing and was a mentor to Bill Gates.
articles.lead_paragraph: Not many people in the computer world remembered H. Edward Roberts, not after he walked away from the industry more than three decades ago to become a country doctor in Georgia. Bill Gates remembered him, though.

articles.headline: Health System Bears Cost of Implants With No Warranties
articles.snippet: The costs of replacing hip or knee implants that fail are largely paid by Medicare, insurers and patients, not the orthopedics industry.
articles.abstract: The costs of replacing hip or knee implants that fail are largely paid by Medicare, insurers and patients, not the orthopedics industry.
articles.lead_paragraph: In January, William R. Morris’s artificial hip, just three years old, was failing so badly that it had to be replaced during an extensive procedure that cost about $50,000.

articles.headline: At 89, Stevens Contemplates Law, and How to Leave It
articles.snippet: Justice John Paul Stevens, who says he will make a decision soon about whether to retire, was candid in reviewing what he has learned about the role of the judge in American life.
articles.abstract: Justice John Paul Stevens, who says he will make a decision soon about whether to retire, was candid in reviewing what he has learned about the role of the judge in American life.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — “There are still pros and cons to be considered,” Justice John Paul Stevens said in his Supreme Court chambers on Friday afternoon, reflecting on his reluctance to leave a job he loves after almost 35 years. But his calculus seemed to be weighted toward departure, and he said his decision on the matter would come very soon.

articles.headline: Violence Helps Taliban Undo Afghan Gains
articles.snippet: The Taliban have killed or beaten people who have received money from the Marines, or they have pocketed it themselves.
articles.abstract: The Taliban have killed or beaten people who have received money from the Marines, or they have pocketed it themselves.
articles.lead_paragraph: MARJA, Afghanistan — Since their offensive here in February, the Marines have flooded Marja with hundreds of thousands of dollars a week. The tactic aims to win over wary residents by paying them compensation for property damage or putting to work men who would otherwise look to the Taliban for support.

articles.headline: Contesting Jobless Claims Becomes a Boom Industry
articles.snippet: The Talx Corporation helps employers process and fight unemployment claims, but critics say its errors and delays keep jobless workers from collecting benefits.
articles.abstract: The Talx Corporation helps employers process and fight unemployment claims, but critics say its errors and delays keep jobless workers from collecting benefits.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — With a client list that reads like a roster of Fortune 500 firms, a little-known company with an odd name, the Talx Corporation, has come to dominate a thriving industry: helping employers process — and fight — unemployment claims.

articles.headline: At CVB Financial, Praise and Questions
articles.snippet: How immune is an admired bank from the real estate crisis?
articles.abstract: How immune is an admired bank from the real estate crisis?
articles.lead_paragraph: THE plaudits are piling up at CVB Financial, the holding company for Citizens Business Bank, a midsize institution with $6.7 billion in assets based in Ontario, Calif.

articles.headline: Bargain Rates for a C.E.O.?
articles.snippet: The median pay package for C.E.O.’s at big public companies declined last year, to $7.7 million. Many critics would say that’s still overpaying.
articles.abstract: The median pay package for C.E.O.’s at big public companies declined last year, to $7.7 million. Many critics would say that’s still overpaying.
articles.lead_paragraph: LAST year may have been unnerving for chief executives accustomed to all of the familiar ornaments of corporate life: eight-figure pay packages, corporate jets, memberships in select clubs, and on and on.

articles.headline: Striking Gold in Stock Options
articles.snippet: The market’s climb has had a multiplier effect on the value of stock options that some C.E.O.’s received early last year.
articles.abstract: The market’s climb has had a multiplier effect on the value of stock options that some C.E.O.’s received early last year.
articles.lead_paragraph: WERE they smart, or just lucky?

articles.headline: Bombs Hit Hub of Diplomacy in Baghdad
articles.snippet: The attacks, at a delicate moment in talks to form a new government, were an attempt by insurgents to retake the initiative after years of retreat.
articles.abstract: The attacks, at a delicate moment in talks to form a new government, were an attempt by insurgents to retake the initiative after years of retreat.
articles.lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD — The Iraqi capital echoed with explosions on Sunday as insurgents sought to exploit political uncertainties created by painstakingly slow talks on forming a new government, with three suicide car bombings at diplomatic targets killing dozens of people and other scattered attacks disrupting areas across Baghdad.
articles.byline: By Rod Nordland and Riyadh Mohammed

articles.headline: Easter Support for Pope, and Some Apologies
articles.snippet: A prominent cardinal stood before Pope Benedict XVI and delivered a show of support in the face of growing anger over the church’s sex abuse scandal.
articles.abstract: A prominent cardinal stood before Pope Benedict XVI and delivered a show of support in the face of growing anger over the church’s sex abuse scandal.
articles.lead_paragraph: VATICAN CITY — A prominent cardinal, in a marked departure from tradition, stood near Pope Benedict XVI at Easter Mass in St. Peter’s Square on Sunday and delivered pointedly public support in the face of growing anger over the Catholic Church’s sex abuse scandal — a topic untouched by the pope in his Easter appearances.

articles.headline: Branding Comes Early in Filmmaking Process
articles.snippet: More writers and producers are cutting branding deals before the movie is cast or the script is fully shaped.
articles.abstract: More writers and producers are cutting branding deals before the movie is cast or the script is fully shaped.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Jordan Yospe had some notes on the script for “The 28th Amendment,” a thriller about a president and a rogue Special Forces agent on the run. Some of the White House scenes were not detailed enough, Mr. Yospe thought. And, he suggested, the heroes should stop for a snack while they were on the lam.

articles.headline: Drones Batter Al Qaeda and Its Allies Within Pakistan
articles.snippet: A stepped-up campaign of American drone strikes has reportedly cast a pall of fear over an area that was once a free zone for Al Qaeda and the Taliban.
articles.abstract: A stepped-up campaign of American drone strikes has reportedly cast a pall of fear over an area that was once a free zone for Al Qaeda and the Taliban.
articles.lead_paragraph: PESHAWAR, Pakistan — A stepped-up campaign of American drone strikes over the past three months has battered Al Qaeda and its Pakistani and Afghan brethren in the tribal area of North Waziristan, according to a mid-ranking militant and supporters of the government there.
articles.byline: By Jane Perlez and Pir Zubair Shah

articles.headline: Weighty Dramas Flourish on Cable
articles.snippet: The broadcast networks still churn out a higher total number of drama hours than the 10 or so basic cable channels in the drama business, but a shift, if not quite a sea change, is taking place.
articles.abstract: The broadcast networks still churn out a higher total number of drama hours than the 10 or so basic cable channels in the drama business, but a shift, if not quite a sea change, is taking place.
articles.lead_paragraph: Television viewers in search of challenging, original drama are flipping past the broadcast networks and going straight to the source: cable channels.

articles.headline: Developers Scramble to Strike iPad Gold
articles.snippet: The creators of the iPhone game Doodle Jump spent Saturday with their new iPad — but they were working, not playing.
articles.abstract: The creators of the iPhone game Doodle Jump spent Saturday with their new iPad — but they were working, not playing.
articles.lead_paragraph: After getting their hands on an Apple iPad on Saturday morning, Igor Pusenjak and his brother Marko rushed back to Igor’s apartment in the Chelsea neighborhood of Manhattan, weaving around languid dogs and seafood deliverymen.

articles.headline: Debunkers of Fictions Sift the Net
articles.snippet: After 14 years of evaluating online rumors at Snopes.com, David and Barbara Mikkelson seem to have concluded that people are rather cavalier about the facts.
articles.abstract: After 14 years of evaluating online rumors at Snopes.com, David and Barbara Mikkelson seem to have concluded that people are rather cavalier about the facts.
articles.lead_paragraph: It is one of the paradoxes of the Internet.

articles.headline: How Sarah Palin Became a Brand
articles.snippet: When Sarah Palin’s bid for the vice presidency failed, she quit her day job and proceeded to become a one-woman national media empire, with the ratings and lucre to show for it.
articles.abstract: When Sarah Palin’s bid for the vice presidency failed, she quit her day job and proceeded to become a one-woman national media empire, with the ratings and lucre to show for it.
articles.lead_paragraph: When Sarah Palin made her debut as the host of “Real American Stories” on Fox News on Thursday night, she described several triumphs of regular people over insurmountable odds, but she missed an obvious one: her own.

articles.headline: Making It Look Easy at The New Yorker
articles.snippet: David Remnick, editor of The New Yorker, has his sixth book, “The Bridge,” coming out on Tuesday, and his magazine was the only one at Condé Nast to avoid budget cuts last year.
articles.abstract: David Remnick, editor of The New Yorker, has his sixth book, “The Bridge,” coming out on Tuesday, and his magazine was the only one at Condé Nast to avoid budget cuts last year.
articles.lead_paragraph: David Remnick, the editor of The New Yorker, is not one to waste an opportunity. After attending John Updike’s funeral in Massachusetts in February of last year, he stopped by Harvard Law School to interview some of President Obama’s old professors. Despite the exhaustive newspaper coverage of the 44th president, Mr. Remnick suspected he had something to add.
